questions.text:
A 38-year-old man reports a 3-day history of ongoing left eye pain, extreme photophobia (leading him to wear sunglasses even when indoors), and decreased vision. He denies any contact lens use, trauma, glaucoma, or mucus discharge from his eyes. He recalls a similar episode 2 years earlier that resolved on its own after 10 days.
On examination, the patient has 20/20 vision in his right eye and 20/40 vision in his left eye. His left eye conjunctiva is markedly injected. The left pupil is sluggishly reactive to light. Both corneas are clear to penlight examination.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Refer to ophthalmology for timolol eyedrops, brimonidine eyedrops, and latanoprost eyedrops
Recommend artificial tears, eyelid scrubs, and warm compresses
Refer to ophthalmology for prednisolone eyedrops and cyclopentolate (cycloplegic) eyedrops
Prescribe ciprofloxacin eyedrops and bacitracin eye ointment
Refer to ophthalmology for erythromycin eyedrops and prednisolone eyedrops

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Timolol, brimonidine, and latanoprost eyedrops are glaucoma medications used to reduce intraocular pressure. Patients with acute angle-closure glaucoma may present with pain, decreased vision, and injection but do not commonly complain of photophobia. On examination, they will have a very shallow anterior chamber and an unresponsive, mid-dilated pupil.

B) INCORRECT:

Artificial tears, eyelid scrubs, and warm compresses are used to treat blepharitis, an inflammation of the eyelids that commonly causes eyelid redness and dry eyes.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with anterior uveitis commonly present with extreme photophobia, eye pain, and injection. On slit-lamp examination, cells can be seen floating in the anterior chamber. Recurrences are common. Treatment of uveitis involves quieting the inflammation, preventing scarring, and controlling pain. If left untreated, inflammation can lead to pupillary adhesions, obstruction of the trabecular meshwork (drainage channels), and ultimately to glaucoma and other vision-threatening problems.

Treatment for anterior uveitis includes both a glucocorticoid eyedrop, such as prednisolone, to help reduce the intraocular inflammation and a mydriatic/cycloplegic (dilating) eye drop, such as cyclopentolate. The mydriatic/cycloplegic eyedrops serve two purposes: They prevent posterior synechiae (adhesions of the pupillary margin to the lens), and they help control pain by relaxing the ciliary muscle.

Key learning point: Initial treatment for an episode of anterior uveitis includes both a glucocorticoid eyedrop (such as prednisolone) and a mydriatic/cycloplegic eyedrop (such as cyclopentolate).

D) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, and bacitracin eyedrops are used to treat ocular infections, which are commonly characterized by mucus discharge and irritation.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, and bacitracin eyedrops are used to treat ocular infections, which are commonly characterized by mucus discharge and irritation.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man reports that his right eye has been red for one week, is sensitive to light, and feels achy. He denies trauma or recent illness, does not wear contact lenses, and feels otherwise well. He was diagnosed with sarcoidosis at 18 years of age, but the disease has been stable and has not required active treatment. He has no history of ocular disease, although he had several episodes of eye redness during the past decade for which he did not seek medical evaluation.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is associated with severe pain, photophobia, a hazy cornea, a fixed dilated pupil, and elevated intraocular pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Episcleritis is characterized by mild ocular discomfort and injected conjunctiva, either diffuse or sectoral. Photophobia and reduced vision are not typical presenting symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Corneal abrasions are typically caused by trauma and are associated with eye pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. An epithelial defect is visible on examination with fluorescein staining.

D) INCORRECT:

Irregular astigmatism is an alteration in the shape of the cornea that may reduce vision but is not associated with redness, pain, or photophobia. Vision compromise due to astigmatism is typically correctable with glasses.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has anterior uveitis, which is an inflammation of the iris and ciliary body characterized by eye pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. Examination may reveal diminished visual acuity, a miotic pupil, conjunctival injection or ciliary flush, a clear cornea, and anterior chamber cells. Intraocular pressure is usually normal, although in some cases it may be elevated or decreased. Patients are often difficult to examine because of photophobia. Although uveitis is typically idiopathic, it is also associated with sarcoidosis, HLA-B27 spondyloarthropathies, and other rheumatologic conditions. Uveitis is treated topically with glucocorticoids and cycloplegics in addition to systemic treatment for the underlying disease.

Key learning point: The most common ophthalmologic complication associated with sarcoidosis is uveitis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is referred from her ophthalmologist with a diagnosis of recurrent uveitis in her right eye. She reports 6 days of right-eye discomfort, injection, and photophobia. The ophthalmologist had noted inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber and inflammatory mutton-fat keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium but no hypopyon. He had also found an enlarged lacrimal gland on the right side.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to help determine the systemic cause of this patientâ€™s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, HLA-B27 test, and interferon-gamma release assay would be appropriate for the assessment of isolated recurrent uveitis (without lacrimal-gland enlargement), especially if other risk factors for sarcoidosis were absent. Sarcoidosis is particularly common among Black people and northern Europeans.

B) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, HLA-B27 test, and interferon-gamma release assay would be appropriate for the assessment of isolated recurrent uveitis (without lacrimal-gland enlargement), especially if other risk factors for sarcoidosis were absent. Sarcoidosis is particularly common among Black people and northern Europeans.

C) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in a patient with recurrent uveitis who has concomitant lacrimal-gland enlargement is sarcoidosis. The initial workup includes a chest radiograph or CT to detect hilar adenopathy. A lacrimal-gland biopsy is useful for definitive diagnosis. Sarcoidosis is particularly common among Black people and northern Europeans.

Therapy for recurrent uveitis involves identifying and treating underlying conditions, as well as treating ocular inflammation. Treatment of the ocular component involves antiinflammatory glucocorticoid eyedrops and topical pupillary dilators to prevent iris adhesions and help alleviate pain. If topical therapy is ineffective, glucocorticoids can be injected intraocularly or periocularly. Oral glucocorticoids and disease-modifying antirheumatic or immunosuppressive drugs are also used when needed.

Key learning point: A patient with recurrent uveitis and lacrimal-gland enlargement should be evaluated for sarcoidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, HLA-B27 test, and interferon-gamma release assay would be appropriate for the assessment of isolated recurrent uveitis (without lacrimal-gland enlargement), especially if other risk factors for sarcoidosis were absent. Sarcoidosis is particularly common among Black people and northern Europeans.

E) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, HLA-B27 test, and interferon-gamma release assay would be appropriate for the assessment of isolated recurrent uveitis (without lacrimal-gland enlargement), especially if other risk factors for sarcoidosis were absent. Sarcoidosis is particularly common among Black people and northern Europeans.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports a 3-day history of increasing photophobia, redness, pain, and blurry vision in her right eye. She denies recent illness or history of eye trauma. She has no significant medical history and does not wear contact lenses. She recalls a similar episode one year ago, for which she did not seek medical attention.
On examination, the patient has 20/80 vision in the right eye and 20/20 vision in the left eye. Examination of the right eye is difficult because of the patient's severe photophobia, but it does reveal miosis and a clear cornea. Examination of the left eye is unremarkable, but the eye is also sensitive to light.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Eye pain, photophobia, and decreased vision are typical symptoms of uveitis, an inflammation of the uveal tract. Anterior uveitis is inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, whereas posterior uveitis refers to inflammation of the choroid. Uveitis is most commonly idiopathic, but when it is recurrent or bilateral, it should raise suspicion for an underlying etiology such as HLA-B27 spondyloarthropathies, sarcoidosis, or other rheumatologic diseases. Infections such as herpes zoster or syphilis can also cause uveitis.

Examination usually reveals decreased visual acuity, a miotic pupil, conjunctival injection or ciliary flush, a clear cornea, and anterior chamber cells. Intraocular pressure is usually normal but may be elevated or decreased. Patients are often difficult to examine because of photophobia. Uveitis is treated with topical glucocorticoids and cycloplegics.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young woman who presents with decreased visual acuity, a clear cornea, a miotic pupil, and photophobia is uveitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with cataracts typically have decreased vision due to an opacification of the lens, without photophobia or redness.

C) INCORRECT:

Scleritis is characterized by pain and redness in the eye without severe photophobia. Vision may be stable or decreased, particularly if there is posterior eye involvement. Scleritis is often associated with systemic diseases, especially rheumatoid arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is associated with severe pain or photophobia, a hazy cornea, a fixed mid-dilated pupil, and elevated intraocular pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with retinal detachment typically describe a painless curtain over a portion of the visual field, photopsias, and floaters.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of increasing photophobia, redness, pain, and blurry vision in her right eye. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to your clinic with a one-week history of redness, photophobia, and aching in his right eye. He denies trauma, recent illness, and does not wear contact lenses. He reports no other symptoms. He was diagnosed with sarcoidosis at age 18, which has remained stable without active treatment. He has no history of ocular disease but reports several episodes of eye redness over the past decade that were not evaluated. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Episcleritis is characterized by mild ocular discomfort and injected conjunctiva, either diffuse or sectoral. Photophobia and reduced vision are not typical presenting symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Irregular astigmatism is an alteration in the shape of the cornea that may reduce vision but is not associated with redness, pain, or photophobia. Vision compromise due to astigmatism is typically correctable with glasses.

C) INCORRECT:

Corneal abrasions are typically caused by trauma and are associated with eye pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. An epithelial defect is visible on examination with fluorescein staining.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is associated with severe pain, photophobia, a hazy cornea, a fixed dilated pupil, and elevated intraocular pressure.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has anterior uveitis, which is an inflammation of the iris and ciliary body characterized by eye pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. Examination may reveal diminished visual acuity, a miotic pupil, conjunctival injection or ciliary flush, a clear cornea, and anterior chamber cells. Intraocular pressure is usually normal, although in some cases it may be elevated or decreased. Patients are often difficult to examine because of photophobia. Although uveitis is typically idiopathic, it is also associated with sarcoidosis, HLA-B27 spondyloarthropathies, and other rheumatologic conditions. Uveitis is treated topically with glucocorticoids and cycloplegics in addition to systemic treatment for the underlying disease.

Key learning point: The most common ophthalmologic complication associated with sarcoidosis is uveitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of left eye pain and photophobia. He reports no trauma, discharge, or contact lens use. Vital signs are normal. On examination, the affected eye shows circumcorneal redness, a constricted and sluggishly reactive pupil, and no purulent discharge. Corneal sensation is preserved. Visual acuity is slightly reduced in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination shows cells and flare in the anterior chamber. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Topical fluoroquinolone drops with primary care follow-up

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct â€“ This patient's presentation with unilateral painful red eye, photophobia, miosis, and anterior chamber inflammation is consistent with anterior uveitis. Prompt ophthalmology consultation is essential to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate therapy such as topical corticosteroids and cycloplegic agents. Delay in management can lead to synechiae formation and permanent vision loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are indicated for bacterial conjunctivitis, which typically manifests with diffuse conjunctival injection and mucopurulent discharge. This patient's symptoms of photophobia and circumcorneal injection are not consistent with bacterial conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antihistamine/decongestant drops are appropriate for allergic conjunctivitis, which manifests with bilateral itching, tearing, and diffuse conjunctival injection. This patient's unilateral pain, photophobia, and anterior chamber inflammation indicate a deeper inflammatory process rather than an allergic etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antiviral therapy is appropriate for viral conjunctivitis, which typically manifests with watery discharge and diffuse conjunctival injection. This patient's circumcorneal redness, miosis, and anterior chamber inflammation indicate a different diagnosis requiring another step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Artificial tears may relieve discomfort in viral conjunctivitis, which manifests with diffuse conjunctival injection and watery discharge. The presence of photophobia and anterior chamber cells indicates a more serious intraocular process.
